Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Integrated Experimental and Computational, Multiscale Study of Geopolymers for Next Generation Soil Improvement

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The role of inorganic geopolymer technology in sustainable development has recently been manifested in a great number of research activities and publications. To date, a wide array of viable applications of geopolymer has been explored, some of which have been demonstrated in field pilot projects. Yet, its potential applications in geotechnical engineering, particularly as a cementitious material for soil improvement, have rarely been studied. Collaborative research under this award will fill this gap, by exploring geopolymer as the next generation soil stabilizer for geotechnical applications. The research program includes: (1) studying the viability of geopolymers for soil improvement, and (2) revealing the fundamental science on the nanoscale geopolymer-clay interactions and hence the soil cementation and stabilization mechanisms. This study will also create the enabling knowledge on multiscale chemo-microstructural-mechanical modeling of geopolymer-improved soils. Integrated experimental and computational work, consisting of materials synthesis and processing, microstructural characterization, multiscale mechanical testing, molecular simulations, and multiscale modeling, will be conducted to achieve the aforementioned goal so that the emerging geopolymer technology can be exploited by geotechnical engineers for sustainable construction. This study is potentially transformative by introducing an innovative, "green" cementitious material to geotechnical engineering research and practice, with the potential to evolve into a series of new technological and economic advancements. Successful completion of the project will further advance currently ongoing worldwide efforts in sustainable infrastructure construction, environmental protection, and energy conservation.

The success of this study is expected to result in benefits to diverse industries such as infrastructure materials and construction, energy conservation, waste utilization and reduction, and environmental protection, because geopolymer is regarded as a "green," energy- and environment-friendly material. This study also tackles a combination of global sustainability issues (e.g., CO2 emission, energy conservation, and environmental protection), and hence is expected to generate significant technological, environmental, and economic impacts. Concurrent education and outreach activities will be integrated into the research to disseminate knowledge, provide training, and facilitate technology transfer. First, outreach will be achieved by high school visits, presentations, attending science fairs/symposia, and other special "MA-Strive" and "La-STEM" programs to attract more students to STEM. Second, undergraduate and graduate training and mentoring are an integrated part of this research, with particular emphasis on women, minority, and/or disadvantaged students. Third, the project's impact will be extended, via meetings and conferences, to engineers in private industries and state agencies through proactive participation in local engineering societies' activities, and prompt dissemination of research findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aimed at developing a new green cementitious material, waste-derived geopolymer, for the next-generation soil improvement technology and uncovering the soil-geopolymer interaction mechanisms. The project outcomes are summarized in two separate categories: intellectual merits and broader impacts of the project.

Project outcomes related to intellectual merits:

As a new class of green cementitious material, geoploymers can be developed from a wide array of industrial byproducts, such as Class C and F fly ash, red mud, furnace slag and metakaolin. Application of this green materials to soil improvement can achieve both economic and environmental benefits, such as low costs, low carbon footprint, and solid waste recycling and reuse, among others. Moreover, geopolymer can be used as an effective, durable, and economical soil stabilizer and have the potential to replace other soil improvement technologies, such as Portland cement, lime, and other chemical-based soil improvement techniques.

A better understanding of the relationship among geopolymer chemical compositions – formation of geopolymer gels – macromechanical properties was achieved through a multiscale experimental study, which can provide guidance for optimizing geopolymer synthesis to achieve desired mechanical performance.

The polymerization process and amorphous geopolymer gels were simulated by reactive molecular dynamics simulations, and the predicted molecular structures of the geopolymer gels can be used for assessing other key properties, such as strength, stiffness and permeability of geopolymer, and providing guidance for synthesizing geopolymer with tailored properties.

Experimental studies also find that, in some special conditions, such as soils with high chemical contents (including saline, sulfate, acid, and alkaline), geopolymer has much better benefits than traditional soil stabilizers, such as Portland cement and lime. This finding is particularly important for some challenging situations where traditional soil stabilizers are not applicable or problematic.

According to the small-scale investigations, geopolymers can act effectively as a binding agent interacting with soil particles and hence improve soil’s strength and stiffness. Moreover, a better understanding of the fly ash-based geopolymer binders for soil improvement has been achieved, including its nanoporosity, chemical resistance to saltwater curing and setting, and reaction kinetics.

This project produces a cost-effective soil stabilizer, especially for sulfate-rich expansive soils, which are a long-lasting challenge for soil stabilization with calcium-based stabilizers, such as lime and cement. The ambient condition-based geopolymerization technology developed in this study can provide a sustainable approach to recycle and reuse two abundant industrial wastes, red mud and fly ash. Therefore, this research also addresses a combination of global issues, including CO2 emission and climate change, energy conservation (e.g., cement manufacturing has been regarded as one of the most energy intensive of man’s activities), waste recycling and reduction for “green” manufacturing and environmental protection, and sustainable infrastructure.

Project outcomes related to broader impacts:

The project has provided training to 13 students in total, including undergraduate and graduate students. Of these students, 7 are women students, which accounts for more than 50%. Moreover, 2 of these women students are of Hispanic origin. One woman student was a graduate from Smith College, one of the top-ranked liberal art colleges. The project has successfully attracted and trained students of diverse origins and backgrounds.

Research results and findings have been and will be continuously disseminated via journal publications and conference proceedings so that the impact can reach out to different communities and various disciplines worldwide. To date, four journal papers have been published, one journal paper has been tentatively accepted for publication, two more journal manuscripts are under review, and three more manuscripts are being prepared now. In addition, results have also been disseminated in four conference presentations.
